pullrequest.title: Model submission for X1 sensor configuration 6.

content.raw: Should we use a PointCloud messages for cliff sensors? I say this because some of the cliff sensors I've seen act more like depth cameras with (eg. Evo 64px http://wiki.ros.org/teraranger). Point cloud messages would make a more consistent interface for single pixel and multi-pixel sensors.
content.html: Should we use a PointCloud messages for cliff sensors? I say this because some of the cliff sensors I've seen act more like depth cameras with (eg. Evo 64px http://wiki.ros.org/teraranger). Point cloud messages would make a more consistent interface for single pixel and multi-pixel sensors.

pullrequest.title: Model submission for X1 sensor configuration 6.

content.raw: For a ground vehicle with the sensor mounted so close to the ground, the difference is fairly negligible.   However, I think that aerial vehicles will benefit from non-LIDAR based sensors.  What range value does a depth camera return from an area?  Is it the minimum, average, or maximum distance from that cell’s area or is it a singular point?
content.html: For a ground vehicle with the sensor mounted so close to the ground, the difference is fairly negligible. However, I think that aerial vehicles will benefit from non-LIDAR based sensors. What range value does a depth camera return from an area? Is it the minimum, average, or maximum distance from that cell’s area or is it a singular point?

pullrequest.title: Model submission for X1 sensor configuration 6.

content.raw: Sorry for the delay. I honestly don't know what range value we get from a depth camera when a pixel covers a large area. @{557058:10b01d41-a2e9-4a41-a907-e6e2f03b6cd5} do you happen to know? If teams are okay with implementing all cliff sensors using the same type of sensor (Lidar in this case), I'm okay using the LaserScan message type.
content.html: Sorry for the delay. I honestly don't know what range value we get from a depth camera when a pixel covers a large area. @Ian Chen do you happen to know? If teams are okay with implementing all cliff sensors using the same type of sensor (Lidar in this case), I'm okay using the LaserScan message type.

pullrequest.title: Model submission for X1 sensor configuration 6.

content.raw:
If we use something like the Kobuki as an example, they publish the bumper and cliff as a point cloud where the point is far away when the sensor isn’t triggered.

Ref: [https://github.com/yujinrobot/kobuki/blob/devel/kobuki\_bumper2pc/src/kobuki\_bumper2pc.cpp](https://github.com/yujinrobot/kobuki/blob/devel/kobuki_bumper2pc/src/kobuki_bumper2pc.cpp)
content.html:
If we use something like the Kobuki as an example, they publish the bumper and cliff as a point cloud where the point is far away when the sensor isn’t triggered.

Ref: https://github.com/yujinrobot/kobuki/blob/devel/kobuki_bumper2pc/src/kobuki_bumper2pc.cpp

pullrequest.title: Model submission for X1 sensor configuration 6.

content.raw: It looks as if their `cliff sensor` is a combination of 3 different single beam sensors on left, center, and right w/r to the front of the vehicle.  To copy their implementation would require another node combining these three sensor messages and publishing a boolean.  I think that’s something to do for the next iteration of the cliff sensor instead of this one.  We could keep the raw measurements accessible so to not break functionality teams build around this.
content.html: It looks as if their cliff sensor is a combination of 3 different single beam sensors on left, center, and right w/r to the front of the vehicle. To copy their implementation would require another node combining these three sensor messages and publishing a boolean. I think that’s something to do for the next iteration of the cliff sensor instead of this one. We could keep the raw measurements accessible so to not break functionality teams build around this.

pullrequest.title: Model submission for X1 sensor configuration 6.

content.raw: Looks like the sensor is pointing straight down. Would that give the vehicle enough time to respond when a cliff is detected?
content.html: Looks like the sensor is pointing straight down. Would that give the vehicle enough time to respond when a cliff is detected?

pullrequest.title: Model submission for X1 sensor configuration 6.

content.raw: Also, at 50 Hz.  At 1 m/s, that’s 2cm of motion between updates, at 5 m/s that’s 10cm… could be tight.
content.html: Also, at 50 Hz. At 1 m/s, that’s 2cm of motion between updates, at 5 m/s that’s 10cm… could be tight.

pullrequest.title: Model submission for X1 sensor configuration 6.

content.raw:
It’s incredibly tight. Luckily no ground vehicles _should_ be traveling at 5 m/s. Also luckily the diff-drive controller responds pretty much instantaneously as-is so you can stop on a dime. In this case, the cliff sensor isn’t supposed to be your only means of detecting vertical drops but more-so a last resort to stop the vehicle from plummeting.

‌

I’m open to other ideas to give more warning for ground vehicles. Wider FoV would help \(slightly, the sensor isn’t far from the ground\), cantilevering the sensor out front would also help, angling the sensor forward might also help.

‌
content.html:
It’s incredibly tight. Luckily no ground vehicles should be traveling at 5 m/s. Also luckily the diff-drive controller responds pretty much instantaneously as-is so you can stop on a dime. In this case, the cliff sensor isn’t supposed to be your only means of detecting vertical drops but more-so a last resort to stop the vehicle from plummeting.

‌

I’m open to other ideas to give more warning for ground vehicles. Wider FoV would help (slightly, the sensor isn’t far from the ground), cantilevering the sensor out front would also help, angling the sensor forward might also help.

‌

pullrequest.title: Model submission for X1 sensor configuration 6.

content.raw: I was thinking of just angling the sensor. An angle of 45 degrees would give us an extra 13cm I think. Then from the center of the wheels, the vehicle has ~38cm to move right after it detects a cliff. At a speed of 2m/s, that's about 200ms (10 samples). I think that would work.
content.html: I was thinking of just angling the sensor. An angle of 45 degrees would give us an extra 13cm I think. Then from the center of the wheels, the vehicle has ~38cm to move right after it detects a cliff. At a speed of 2m/s, that's about 200ms (10 samples). I think that would work.

pullrequest.title: Model submission for X1 sensor configuration 6.

content.raw: 45 degrees is tolerable.  The only consideration here is that the angle needs to be at least greater than the maximum traversable slope \(probably 20-30 degrees maximum\) by some non-trivial amount to return a value that doesn’t result in a headache from edge cases and probably less than the overall slope of the stairs \(which would be 45 degrees if the stairs are uniform\).
content.html: 45 degrees is tolerable. The only consideration here is that the angle needs to be at least greater than the maximum traversable slope (probably 20-30 degrees maximum) by some non-trivial amount to return a value that doesn’t result in a headache from edge cases and probably less than the overall slope of the stairs (which would be 45 degrees if the stairs are uniform).

pullrequest.title: Model submission for X1 sensor configuration 6.

content.raw: I ended up going with -40 degrees from the X plane \(50 degrees from straight down\) . This works well for stairs and the inclines encountered in the environment.  It would only be a problem as down-slopes approach 40 degrees \(which we shouldn’t have\).
content.html: I ended up going with -40 degrees from the X plane (50 degrees from straight down) . This works well for stairs and the inclines encountered in the environment. It would only be a problem as down-slopes approach 40 degrees (which we shouldn’t have).

pullrequest.title: Model submission for X1 sensor configuration 6.

content.raw:
The pose of the cliff sensor is below the front bumper and since the the sensor doesn't have a collision, it can go through objects. If you move the vehicle right up against a staircase, the range reading goes to max because the sensor is now under the step. 
To reproduce this, run:
```
ign launch -v 4 urban_circuit.ign worldName:=urban_circuit_practice_02 robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_6 localModel:=true
```
```
ign service -s /world/urban_circuit_practice_02/set_pose --reqtype ignition.msgs.Pose --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean --timeout 300 --req 'name: "X1", position { x: -41.123805757753146 y: -83.4070592226983 z: -9.48707739676623 }, orientation { x: 2.4298477166436454e-07 y: 2.4329190216765405e-07 z: 0.70712632436422229 w: 0.70708723746863533 }'
```

I suggest moving the sensor up by 0.11 so it's attached to the front bumper. Thanks to @{557058:10b01d41-a2e9-4a41-a907-e6e2f03b6cd5} who made this observation.
content.html:
The pose of the cliff sensor is below the front bumper and since the the sensor doesn't have a collision, it can go through objects. If you move the vehicle right up against a staircase, the range reading goes to max because the sensor is now under the step. To reproduce this, run:

ign launch -v 4 urban_circuit.ign worldName:=urban_circuit_practice_02 robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_6 localModel:=true

ign service -s /world/urban_circuit_practice_02/set_pose --reqtype ignition.msgs.Pose --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean --timeout 300 --req 'name: "X1", position { x: -41.123805757753146 y: -83.4070592226983 z: -9.48707739676623 }, orientation { x: 2.4298477166436454e-07 y: 2.4329190216765405e-07 z: 0.70712632436422229 w: 0.70708723746863533 }'

I suggest moving the sensor up by 0.11 so it's attached to the front bumper. Thanks to @Ian Chen who made this observation.

pullrequest.title: Model submission for X1 sensor configuration 6.

content.raw:
Updated forward/rear sensors to be angled \(50 degrees from perpendicular w/r to the ground plane\).  Moved sensors up in Z to link w/ collision and avoid clipping through the world.

‌

Tested functionality with:

* Approach and touching ascending stairs \(forward \+ rear\)
* Approaching and looking over descending stairs \(forward \+ rear\)
* Approaching and looking over ramp \(forward \+ rear\)

‌
content.html:
Updated forward/rear sensors to be angled (50 degrees from perpendicular w/r to the ground plane). Moved sensors up in Z to link w/ collision and avoid clipping through the world.

‌

Tested functionality with:

  • Approach and touching ascending stairs (forward + rear)
  • Approaching and looking over descending stairs (forward + rear)
  • Approaching and looking over ramp (forward + rear)

‌
